content.text: Python For Loops
Python For Loops
A for loop is used for iterating over a sequence (that is either a list, a tuple, a dictionary, a set, or a string).
content.html: A for loop is used for iterating over a sequence (that is either a list, a tuple, a dictionary, a set, or a string).

content.text: This is less like the for keyword in other programming languages, and works more like an iterator method as found in other object-orientated programming languages.
content.html: This is less like the for keyword in other programming languages, and works more like an iterator method as found in other object-orientated programming languages.

content.text: With the for loop we can execute a set of statements, once for each item in a list, tuple, set etc.
content.html: With the for loop we can execute a set of statements, once for each item in a list, tuple, set etc.

content.code_html:
fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
for x in fruits:
  print(x)

content.text: The for loop does not require an indexing variable to set beforehand.
content.html: The for loop does not require an indexing variable to set beforehand.

content.text: Looping Through a String
Even strings are iterable objects, they contain a sequence of characters:
content.html: Even strings are iterable objects, they contain a sequence of characters:

content.code_html:
for x in "banana":
  print(x)

content.text: The break Statement
With the break statement we can stop the loop before it has looped through all the items:
content.html: With the break statement we can stop the loop before it has looped through all the items:

content.code_html:
fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
for x in fruits:
  print(x)
  if x == "banana":
    break

syntaxHighlighting.text:
fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]for x in fruits:  if x == 
  "banana":    break  print(x)

content.code:
fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]for x in fruits:  if x ==
"banana":    break  print(x)

syntax_highlighting.text:
fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]for x in fruits:  if x == 
 "banana":    break  print(x)

content.code_html:
fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
for x in fruits:
  if x == "banana":
    break
  print(x)

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]for x in fruits:  if x == 
  "banana":    break  print(x)

content.text: The continue Statement
With the continue statement we can stop the current iteration of the loop, and continue with the next:
content.html: With the continue statement we can stop the current iteration of the loop, and continue with the next:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]for x in fruits:  if x == 
  "banana":    continue  print(x)

content.code:
fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]for x in fruits:  if x ==
"banana":    continue  print(x)

syntax_highlighting.text:
fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]for x in fruits:  if x == 
 "banana":    continue  print(x)

content.code_html:
fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
for x in fruits:
  if x == "banana":
    continue
  print(x)

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]for x in fruits:  if x == 
  "banana":    continue  print(x)

content.text: The range() Function
The range() function returns a sequence of numbers, starting from 0 by default, and increments by 1 (by default), and ends at a specified number.
content.html: The range() function returns a sequence of numbers, starting from 0 by default, and increments by 1 (by default), and ends at a specified number.

content.code_html:
for x in range(6):
  print(x)

content.text: Note that range(6) is not the values of 0 to 6, but the values 0 to 5.
content.html: Note that range(6) is not the values of 0 to 6, but the values 0 to 5.

content.text: The range() function defaults to 0 as a starting value, however it is possible to specify the starting value by adding a parameter: range(2, 6) , which means values from 2 to 6 (but not including 6):
content.html: The range() function defaults to 0 as a starting value, however it is possible to specify the starting value by adding a parameter: range(2, 6), which means values from 2 to 6 (but not including 6):

content.code_html:
for x in range(2, 6):
  print(x)

content.text: The range() function defaults to increment the sequence by 1, however it is possible to specify the increment value by adding a third parameter: range(2, 30, 3 ) :
content.html: The range() function defaults to increment the sequence by 1, however it is possible to specify the increment value by adding a third parameter: range(2, 30, 3):

content.code_html:
for x in range(2, 30, 3):
  print(x)

content.text: Else in For Loop
The else keyword in a for loop specifies a block of code to be executed when the loop is finished:
content.html: The else keyword in a for loop specifies a block of code to be executed when the loop is finished:

content.code_html:
for x in range(6):
  print(x)
else:
  print("Finally finished!")

content.text: Note: The else block will NOT be executed if the loop is stopped by a break statement.
content.html: Note: The else block will NOT be executed if the loop is stopped by a break statement.

syntaxHighlighting.text:
for x in range(6):  if x == 3: break 
	print(x)else: 
	print("Finally finished!")

content.code:
for x in range(6):  if x == 3: break
print(x)else:
print("Finally finished!")

syntax_highlighting.text:
for x in range(6):  if x == 3: break 
	print(x)else: 
	print("Finally finished!")

content.code_html:
for x in range(6):
  if x == 3: break
  print(x)
else:
  print("Finally finished!")

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
for x in range(6):  if x == 3: break 
	print(x)else: 
	print("Finally finished!")

content.text: Nested Loops
A nested loop is a loop inside a loop.
content.html: A nested loop is a loop inside a loop.

content.text: The "inner loop" will be executed one time for each iteration of the "outer loop":
content.html: The "inner loop" will be executed one time for each iteration of the "outer loop":

syntaxHighlighting.text:
adj = ["red", "big", "tasty"]fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
  for x in adj:  for y in fruits:    print(x, y)

content.code:
adj = ["red", "big", "tasty"]fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
for x in adj:  for y in fruits:    print(x, y)

syntax_highlighting.text:
adj = ["red", "big", "tasty"]fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
 for x in adj:  for y in fruits:    print(x, y)

content.code_html:
adj = ["red", "big", "tasty"]
fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]

for x in adj:
  for y in fruits:
    print(x, y)

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
adj = ["red", "big", "tasty"]fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
  for x in adj:  for y in fruits:    print(x, y)

content.text: The pass Statement
for loops cannot be empty, but if you for some reason have a for loop with no content, put in the pass statement to avoid getting an error.
content.html: for loops cannot be empty, but if you for some reason have a for loop with no content, put in the pass statement to avoid getting an error.

content.code_html:
for x in [0, 1, 2]:
  pass

content.text: Exercise ? What is this? Test your skills by answering a few questions about the topics of this page
What will be the result of the following code: for x in range(3): print(x)
content.html:
What will be the result of the following code:
for x in range(3):
  print(x)
